awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Data Driven Control of Switched Systems with Applications to Human Behavioral Modification
awd_abstract_narration:
Dramatically increasing health care costs threaten the nation's economy. Over 80% of those costs are due to chronic illnesses which can be prevented or mitigated through lifestyle change. Physical activity is also a key behavioral component of ideal cardiovascular health. This suggests that promoting physical activity through the personalized virtual health advisors can lead to substantial health improvements across a broad spectrum of the population. Motivated by these observations, this proposal seeks to develop a tractable, practical framework for designing personalized behavior monitoring systems, aimed at maintaining optimal levels of physical activity. This is accomplished by embedding the problem into a more general, systems-theoretic one:  design of controllers with provable performance for systems characterized by a collection of models where neither the number of models nor their parameters are a priori known and must be obtained from experimental data, collected from multiple sensors with large variations in quality. Education is proactively integrated into this project, starting with STEM summer camps projects for urban middle school students on data driven modeling and continuing at the college level with a multi-disciplinary program that uses personalized medicine to link a full range of distinct subjects ranging from machine learning to systems theory and optimization. At the graduate level, these activities are complemented by recruitment efforts that leverage the resources of Penn State's McNair Scholars Program and Northeastern University's Program in Multicultural Engineering to broaden the participation of underrepresented groups in research. 

Motivated by the problem of designing effective behavioral interventions, this proposal seeks to develop a comprehensive, computationally tractable framework for synthesizing data driven control laws for a class of systems described by switched difference inclusions. These models arise in a broad class of domains, ranging from resilient infrastructures to health care, characterized by large amounts of uncertainty and abruptly changing dynamics. The research addresses both the identification and control design problems in a unified framework based on polynomial optimization and its connections to the problem of moments. Contributions to the field of identification include the development of a tractable framework for robust identification of uncertain switched systems that exploits the underlying structure of the problem to substantially reduce the computational complexity and can handle both worst case and risk-adjusted descriptions. Contributions to control include a new framework for chance constrained control of uncertain switched systems that maximizes the probability of achieving a desired final state, while, at the same time, minimizing the probability of entering bad sets. As a proof-of-principle, the resulting framework is applied to the problem of designing smartphone based virtual health advisors capable of providing individualized optimal physical activity strategies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Summary: Motivated by the problem of designing effective behavioral interventions, this proposal developed a comprehensive, computationally tractable framework for synthesizing data driven control laws for systems described by switched difference inclusions. These models, arising in a broad class of domains, ranging from resilient infrastructures to health care, are characterized by large amounts of uncertainty and abruptly changing dynamics. As a proof-of-principle, the PIs applied  the resulting framework to the problems of (1) human activity analysis and (2), in collaboration with  Penn State colleagues,  design of virtual health advisors capable of providing individualized optimal physical activity strategies that decrease the health risks associated with sedentary behavior.

Intellectual Merit:  This research advanced the state of the art in the disciplines contributing to the project, as follows:

Systems Identification: The problem of identifying models and uncertainty descriptions amenable to be used by existing hybrid control methods is far from solved, even when using worst-case descriptions. This proposal aimed at closing this gap by developing a computationally tractable framework for robust identification of these models, by combining tools from systems theory, machine learning and polynomial optimization. The advantages of this new  approach include the ability to: (a) Address problems beyond the capabilities of existing identification and machine learning techniques, due to a combination of poor scaling properties, substantial uncertainty and the need to provide both worst case and risk-adjusted descriptions. (b) Accommodate features that are key to success in the relevant application domains. In particular, for the health care applications, a model must provide a good trade off between complexity and uncertainty "size".  A model that is too complex will result in over-fitting of the data and, hence, it may not have enough power to predict future behavior of the individual being treated.

Control of Uncertain Systems: This research took initial steps towards developing a computationally tractable framework for data driven control of systems characterized by time varying, not necessarily linear dynamics, structural  constraints, and potentially high dimensional data. Currently existing methods cannot handle the combination of a-priori unknown switching dynamics and high dimensional data, due to an exponential explosion in computational complexity. We have shown that in many practical scenarios tools from robust optimization can be exploited to synthesize robust controllers directly from experimental data. Further, these controllers are guaranteed to avoid unsafe sets.

Machine Learning: This research extended machine learning techniques such as manifold embedding and subspace clustering to handle dynamical data, and by incorporating dynamics based layers into the popular deep learning framework. 

Convex Optimization: The  research advanced the state of the art in convex optimization by developing efficient algorithms for solving large semi-definite programs. Since semi-definite programs are at the core of many techniques in areas ranging from control and signal processing to machine learning, we expect a substantial impact in these areas, by rendering feasible problems currently beyond the capabilities of existing techniques.

Broader Impact: Dramatically increasing health care costs threaten the nation’s economy. Over 80% of those costs are due to chronic illnesses which can be prevented or mitigated through lifestyle change. For example, physical inactivity increases risk for common cancers to the extent that 9-19% of new cancers are attributed to insufficient physical activity. This suggests that promoting physical activity through the use of personalized “virtual health advisors” enabled by the framework that we developed in this research can lead to substantial health improvements across a broad spectrum of the population. In addition, these advisors can offer real time monitoring of health status, support adoption of a healthy lifestyle, provide rapid diagnosis of health conditions and provide the means to implement effective “just-in-time” interventions, thus reducing the burden on the healthcare system.

Educational Impact:  This project provided opportunities for research and teaching in the fields that contribute to the project (Machine Learning, Control Theory and Optimization). This is expected to contribute to the future work force who will require skills both in Electrical Engineering (Control Theory) and Computer Science (Machine Learning), as well as a working knowledge of optimization techniques. Specifically: Two undergraduate students were exposed very early on in their careers to concepts from control theory, machine learning and computer vision that normally would not be covered until their senior year. A Ph.D. student involved in this project developed a framework for data driven control of uncertain dynamical systems, based on a combination of tools from non-linear control and convex optimization. A second Ph.D. student developed a theoretical framework to assess safety of a given non-linear control policy in the face of uncertainty (uncertain initial conditions and dynamics). A third Ph.D. student developed Koopman-inspired deep neural networks for video distenglament and interpretation. A fourth Ph.D. student took initial steps towards developing neural networks to capture dynamics-based invariants from video sequences, combining recent advances in Machine Learning with concepts from Control Theory and Systems Identification.
